name: Hofskirkja
description: Hofskirkja is Iceland's last turf church built in the traditional style and the youngest of only six remaining turf churches in the country, all of which are protected as national historical monuments. Located in the village of Hof in Öræfi, southeastern Iceland, approximately 20 kilometers southeast of Skaftafell in Vatnajökull National Park and 87 kilometers east of Kirkjubæjarklaustur, the church sits dramatically beneath Hvannadalshnjúkur, Iceland's highest peak at 2,110 meters. The current structure was originally constructed in 1884 by Páll Pálsson, a renowned Icelandic carpenter, and dedicated to Saint Clement. The church underwent thorough restoration between 1953 and 1954 by the National Museum of Iceland and was reconsecrated in 1954. However, churches have occupied this sacred site for over 700 years, with the oldest written records appearing in a medieval document from 1343, establishing Hofskirkja as one of Iceland's most historically significant religious locations. The church exemplifies traditional Icelandic turf architecture, featuring a timber skeleton surrounded by sturdy stone walls that provide structural support. The roof is capped by heavy stone slabs covered with layers of turf and grass, creating a distinctive green covering that helps retain heat and provides natural insulation against Iceland's harsh climate. The building is partially buried into the earth, allowing the ground itself to serve as additional insulation—a crucial adaptation for survival in the sub-Arctic environment. This construction technique was common throughout Iceland until the early 20th century when modern building materials became more accessible. The church interior is divided into a nave and choir, separated by a traditional chancel screen, with the walls painted in vibrant colors that contrast strikingly with the earthy exterior. Unlike several other preserved turf churches that function purely as museums, Hofskirkja remains an active practicing parish church, occasionally holding services for the local community. The National Museum of Iceland maintains Hofskirkja as part of its historical house collection, preserving this unique example of Iceland's architectural heritage. However, the church is now closed to the public for interior visits, with the building and grounds fenced off for preservation. Visitors can admire the distinctive grass-covered exterior and photograph the church from the perimeter fence. The site is conveniently located just off Ring Road (Route 1), accessible via Hofsvegur road with a five-minute drive from the main highway. Free parking is available directly adjacent to the church grounds, making it an easy and worthwhile stop for travelers exploring Iceland's South Coast between Vík and Höfn.
